trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised trial of stretching before and after physical activity to prevent soreness and reduce risk of injury
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does stretching before and after physical activity prevent soreness and reduce risk of injury more than no stretching in people who do recreational exercise?

interventions.interventions: stretching of back and leg muscles (7 muscle groups, both sides, 30 seconds) before and after exercise for a 12 week period
interventions.comparator: no stretching of back or leg muscles

primaryOutcome.timepoint: longitudinal design (soreness is evaluated weekly for 12 weeks)
survival analysis of times to injuries observed in a 12 week monitoring period

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: longitudinal design (soreness is evaluated weekly for 12 weeks)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: injuries for which medical attention is sought
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: survival analysis of times to injuries observed in a 12 week monitoring

secondaryOutcome.outcome: injuries that might be prevented by stretching
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: survival analysis of times to injuries observed in a 12 week monitoring period

secondaryOutcome.outcome: perception of "looseness" during and after exercise (11-point scale)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: longitudinal design (looseness is evaluated weekly for 12 weeks)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. aged 18 years or over. 2. able to read and write in English or Norwegian. 3. takes part in vigorous physical activity on at least one day in the past week 4. regularly accesses internet and email 5. willing to stop stretching (if currently stretching) or begin stretching (if currently not stretching) before and after exercise
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: has a lower limb or back injury that restricts participation in vigorous physical activity

trial_design.concealment: Participants visit the trial web site and answer screening questions. If they are eligible and consent they are randomised online.

recruitment.postcode: The trial is internet-based and open to the whole world of English and Norwegian speakers

fundingsource.fundingname: New South Wales Sporting Injuries Commission

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary objectives of this trial are to determine if a program of stretching before and after vigorous physical activity reduces risk of experiencing soreness after physical activity or reduces the risk of incurring an injury while participating in vigorous physical activity. The trial is internet-based and open to the whole world of English and Norwegian speakers.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Jamtvedt G, Herbert RD, Flottorp S, et al. A pragmatic randomised trial of stretching before and after physical activity to prevent injury and soreness. British Journal of Sports Medicine 2010;44:1002-9.
